paper_decoration.summary: The manuscript features gold-sprinkled margins (yaldız serpmeli kenarlar) throughout the text block, confirmed on both the opening pages (p007) and a regular text opening (p010). The gold sprinkling appears consistently applied across all examined text pages, indicating a unified decorative programme rather than selective treatment. The margins are framed by multi-line cetvels in gold, black, and red (altın cetvelli), forming a coordinated yaldız serpmeli kenar with altın cetvel decorative system standard in Ottoman luxury manuscripts of the classical period. Additionally, p007 presents a double-page illuminated serlevha (başlık tezhibi) in lapis blue (lacivert) and gold with hatāyī and rūmī motifs, confirming this as a luxury commission.

key_indicators: Double-page serlevha (double başlık tezhibi) indicating significant patronage and a unified commission
Lapis blue (lacivert) and gold palette in serlevha consistent with Ottoman classical illumination
Hatāyī and rūmī motif combination characteristic of nakkaşhane-i hümayun output and its provincial emulators
Gold-sprinkled margins (yaldız serpmeli) extending throughout the text block — standard in Ottoman luxury production from the mid-16th century
Multi-line cetvels in gold, black, and red framing text: coordinated system consistent with Istanbul or high-quality Anatolian workshop
cross_tradition_caveats: Konya (Yusuf Ağa) provenance allows for provincial Anatolian production imitating Istanbul court style; without higher-resolution images the quality level cannot be definitively assessed
Date range cannot be narrowed without examining motif details at higher resolution — the double serlevha format spans the 16th and 17th centuries
No colophon, scribal, or patron data available in source materials to confirm workshop identity

paper_decoration.details: This image shows the front cover of the binding, not a paper folio. The binding features a red/maroon leather cover with a central gold şemse (medallion) of an elongated oval form, gold salbek (pendant) extensions above and below, and gold köşebend (corner pieces). The central medallion has a cream/ivory centre with gold border. This is a classic Ottoman binding format. No paper decoration is visible in this image.

style_attribution.justification: The red leather binding with gold-stamped şemse, salbek, and köşebend is a standard Ottoman binding form used across several centuries. Without seeing details of the tooling patterns, more precise dating is not possible.

paper_decoration.details: This is the key decorative opening of the manuscript. Both pages feature illuminated serlevha (headpieces) at the top — a double-page serlevha opening indicating a luxury production. The headpieces feature a lapis blue (lacivert) ground with gold and polychrome decoration. Below the headpieces, the text is written in nastaʿlīq within multi-line gold cetvels. The margins surrounding the text blocks show a warm golden tone consistent with gold sprinkling (yaldız serpmeli), as described in the catalogue. The gold cetvels are clearly visible as multiple parallel lines (gold, black, and possibly red) framing the text area. This opening confirms the manuscript has a coordinated decorative programme: serlevha + cetvels + gold-sprinkled margins.

style_attribution.workshop: Ottoman court or high-quality provincial production — the double-page serlevha indicates significant patronage
style_attribution.justification: The double-page serlevha with lapis-and-gold colour scheme is a hallmark of Ottoman luxury manuscript production. The coordinated programme of illuminated headpieces, gold cetvels, and gold-sprinkled margins indicates a unified commission. The mecmûʿa format and Konya (Yusuf Ağa) provenance could suggest production for a Konya-based patron or donation. More detailed motif analysis would require higher resolution.

bibliography.citation: Blair, Sheila. 'Color and Gold: The Decorated Papers Used in Manuscripts in Later Islamic Times.' Muqarnas XVII (2000): 24–36.
bibliography.relevance: Foundational study of decorated papers in Islamic manuscripts including gold-sprinkled (zerefşân/zarafshān) technique, production methods, and regional distribution. Directly relevant to the gold-sprinkled margins confirmed in this manuscript.
bibliography.access_notes: Peer-reviewed; available through JSTOR and Brill.

bibliography.citation: Bloom, Jonathan M. Paper Before Print: The History and Impact of Paper in the Islamic World. New Haven: Yale University Press, 2001.
bibliography.relevance: Comprehensive study of paper production and use in the Islamic world, including decorated and prepared papers. Provides material context for understanding gold-sprinkled paper in Ottoman manuscripts.
bibliography.access_notes: Monograph; widely held in research libraries.

bibliography.citation: Tanındı, Zeren. 'Bibliophile Aghas (Eunuchs) at Topkapı Sarayı.' Muqarnas 21 (2004): 333–343.
bibliography.relevance: Study of Ottoman court manuscript patronage and the decorated manuscript programmes sponsored by high-ranking officials. Relevant for contextualising gold-sprinkled luxury manuscripts in the Ottoman tradition and potential Konya-based patronage.
bibliography.access_notes: Peer-reviewed; available through JSTOR and Brill.

bibliography.citation: Çağman, Filiz, and Zeren Tanındı. The Topkapı Saray Museum: The Albums and Illustrated Manuscripts. Boston: Little, Brown, 1986.
bibliography.relevance: Authoritative reference for Ottoman illumination programmes, album formats, and the decorative conventions of the Istanbul court. Provides comparative material for the double-page serlevha format and hatāyī-rūmī illumination visible on p007.
bibliography.access_notes: Exhibition catalogue / monograph; English. Widely held.

bibliography.citation: Gacek, Adam. The Arabic Manuscript Tradition: A Glossary of Technical Terms and Bibliography. Leiden: Brill, 2001.
bibliography.relevance: Standard reference for codicological terminology used in Arabic and Islamic manuscript cataloguing. Useful for cross-referencing the Arabic equivalents of Ottoman technical terms (jadwal, ʿunwān, dhahab marsūsh) used in this record.

bibliography.citation: Gacek, Adam. Arabic Manuscripts: A Vademecum for Readers. Leiden: Brill, 2009.
bibliography.relevance: Updated reference covering page layout terms, ruling systems (jadwal/cedvel), and paper decoration terminology. Directly applicable to the cataloguing conventions used in this record.

bibliography.citation: Déroche, François, ed. Islamic Codicology: An Introduction to the Study of Manuscripts in Arabic Script. London: Al-Furqan Islamic Heritage Foundation, 2005.
bibliography.relevance: Authoritative codicological reference covering binding structures, ruling, paper preparation, and decorated papers. Provides the classificatory framework underlying motif type analysis in this project.
bibliography.access_notes: Monograph; English translation of the French original. Widely held.

bibliography.citation: Mahir, Banu. Osmanlı Minyatür Sanatı. Istanbul: Kabalcı Yayınevi, 2005. [In Turkish]
bibliography.relevance: Reference for Ottoman miniature and illumination conventions, including the serlevha format and the decorative programmes of luxury Ottoman manuscripts.
bibliography.access_notes: Monograph; Turkish. Available in Turkish research libraries and Konya collections.

bibliography.citation: Scheper, Karin. The Technique of Islamic Bookbinding: Methods, Materials and Regional Varieties. Leiden: Brill, 2015.
bibliography.relevance: Systematic study of Islamic bookbinding materials and structures. Relevant to the Ottoman şemse-salbek binding documented on p003, including the red leather cover, gold-stamped decoration, and general binding typology.

bibliography.citation: Roxburgh, David J. The Persian Album, 1400–1600: From Dispersal to Collection. New Haven: Yale University Press, 2005.
bibliography.relevance: Study of decorated papers and luxury manuscript culture in the Persianate tradition, including gold-sprinkled papers, their production context, and their relationship to Ottoman court tastes. Background for understanding the zarafshān/zerefşân technique and its cross-cultural transmission.

suggested_collections.reason: Holds the core Ottoman court collection and largest concentration of luxury Ottoman manuscripts with gold-sprinkled margins and double-page serlevha programmes comparable to this manuscript. Essential for stylistic comparison.

The project corpus includes confirmed gold-sprinkled Ottoman manuscripts from Nuruosmaniye (03880, 04100, 03821, 02295). Direct comparison across the confirmed corpus would situate this Yusuf Ağa manuscript in the broader Ottoman zerefşân tradition.

Major international collection of Ottoman luxury manuscripts with digitized high-resolution images. Particularly useful for comparative analysis of double-page serlevha programmes and gold-sprinkled margin conventions.

provenance.notes: Held in the Yusuf Ağa Kütüphanesi, Konya — a collection founded by the waqf (pious endowment) of Yusuf Ağa. This is the second risale of composite volume YY00006636 (see also yusuf_aga_yy00006636-001 for the first risale). The project-internal suffix '-002' distinguishes this risale in the catalog; the physical shelfmark is YY00006636. Manuscripts in the Yusuf Ağa collection are accessible via the YEK portal (Yazma Eserler Kurumu Başkanlığı), which manages provincial Ottoman manuscript collections across Turkey.

analysis_metadata.image_quality_notes: All four images are viewer screenshots at approximately 1536×864 px. This resolution is sufficient to confirm the presence of gold-sprinkled margins and the general structure of the double-page serlevha, but does not allow detailed motif analysis within the headpieces or precise sub-type classification of the rūmī and hatāyī elements. Gold sprinkling on p005 (preliminary leaf) is below the reliable detection threshold at this resolution; confirmation for that folio relies on the catalogue description and corroborating evidence from p007 and p010.
analysis_metadata.folios_not_examined: The majority of the manuscript's folios were not examined. Only four targeted screenshots were available from the visual confirmation batch. A full codicological description would require examination of additional folios including colophon, catchword pages, and a systematic sample of text pages.
